Award.AwardTitle: Workshop for Undergraduate and MS Female Students in Speech Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The workshop is intended for women undergraduate and masters students who are currently working in speech science and technology. It will be held at Interspeech 2017, in Stockholm, and will feature panel discussions with senior female speech science and technology researchers, student poster presentations, and a mentoring session. The workshop is designed to foster interest in research in the field of speech science and technology in women at the undergraduate or masters level who have not yet committed to getting a PhD in speech science or technology areas but who have had some research experience in their college and universities on individual or group projects in those areas.

The motivation for the workshop is the realization on the part of many women researchers in the speech science and technology fields that there seem to be relatively few junior women researchers in the 'pipeline' to careers in speech. This issue is addressed by providing a venue where students in speech science and technology can present their work to each other and to senior women researchers, and where senior women can describe their own research and career experience to students and mentor them. The first workshop was held in San Francisco in 2016 and was very successful and inspirational for young women students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the workshops  is to encourage young female researchers to pursue graduate studies in speech processing. The workshops was attended by faculty from various universities, and researches from industry and government agencies. Between 20-30 undergraduate and MS students attended each workshop and presented their research. Several panels comprising PhD students, faculty, and those working in industry were also held. Students were from Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, Computational Linguistics and related fields. The panels and mentoring sessions provided opportunities for students to practice presenting their research and discussing it. Feedback was very positive. The workshops were held in 2017, 2018 , and 2019 to encourage female students, who are underrepresented in the field, to pursue graduate work. The workshops were held in conjunction with Interspeech 2017 in Stockholm, Interpseech 2018 in Hyderabad, and Interspeech 2019 in Graz.  In fact, these workshops will continue annually. We are thankful to NSF for intitating these workshops. Many female students were inspired by the workshop to pursue graduate careers in STEM and related areas. The quality of the presentations was quite good and a best poster award was initiiated in 2018 to acknowledge the students' work. In fact, several companies (Apple, Google, IBM, Nuance, LDC, and others) became interested and decided to support the workshops financially and by sending representatives.
